awd_titl_txt: 2014 CPS Medical Devices Workshop Travel Support
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal provides for travel of participants of the 2014 CPS Workshop on Medical Frontiers in Research.  The workshop is bringing together multi-disciplinary experts from industry, academia, and government to discuss future CPS research challenges in this space.  The participants are expert in the foundational science, engineering, and technology underlying next-generation cyber-physical systems, particularly in the context of the application domain of medicine, including medical devices.  Through sessions on CPS research in sensing, diagnosis, and prosthetics, the attendees are defining a compelling research agenda in an area of scientific, technical, and engineering exploration that has tremendous societal impact.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report for award NSF CNS-1430010, 2014 CPS
Medical Devices Workshop Travel Subsidies, provides a summary of
the 2014 CPS Workshop on Medical Frontiers in Research.  This
project was closely overseen by NSF CPS Program Director
Dr. David Corman, and the PI is very grateful for his support.

The workshop took place February 6-7, 2014 at the Waterview 
Conference Center in Arlington, VA, and brought together 
multi-disciplinary experts from industry, academia, and government to 
discuss future CPS research challenges in this space.  The participants 
were experts in the foundational science, engineering, and technology 
underlying next-generation cyber-physical systems, particularly in the
application domain of medicine, including medical devices.

The workshop featured three tracks: Monitoring and Diagnosis;
Modeling, Verification and Trustworthiness; and Intervention,
Control and Prosthetics.  Each track comprised three 20-min
Invited Plenary Talks, three Short 5-min Presentations on Highlighted
Whitepapers, four 7-min Breakout Report topic discussions, and one
30-min general discussion period.  With this structure in place, the
workshop attendees were able to define a compelling research agenda
in an area of scientific, technical, and engineering exploration with
significant potential societal impact.

A key outcome of the project was the Workshop Web Site hosted at 
https://cps-vo.org/group/2014MedicalCPSWkshp.  The web site contains
a wide array of information about the 2014 NSF Medical CPS Workshop,
including the agenda, speaker bios, presentations, registrants
list, and the workshop final report.  The PIs are grateful to Frankie
King, School of Engineering, Vanderbilt University, for developing and
managing the project web site and for her support in organizing the
workshop.

Track 1: Monitoring and Diagnosis

This track focused on problems related to data collection and usage in
medical CPS.  Monitoring is a two-fold problem in this field: precise
information is needed, but the sheer amount of available data can often
"drown out" what is needed in the given moment.  We must use CPS
solutions both to improve monitoring, and use discovered data in an
intelligent manner to help with diagnosis.

This track featured the following plenary talks:

Wearable Sensor Systems for Long-Term Health and Environmental
Monitoring, Veena Misra, NCSU.  This talk focused on the use of
nanotechnology to build a new class of sensors.  These devices push
the boundaries of modern wearable technologies by cutting power costs
and traditional rigidity while offering innovative new solutions in
energy harvesting.

How a Wealth of Information Begets a Poverty of Attention: The Special
Case of Data Overload in the ICU, J. Perren Cobb, M.D., Director of
the Massachusetts General Hospital Critical Care Center.  This talk
focused on arising problems in the ICU from an over-abundance of data.

Track 2: Modeling, Verification and Trustworthiness

This track focused on the problem of defining trustworthiness in 
Medical CPS models and systems, and how to build models that are
realistic enough that their verification results are useful.

If featured the following plenary talks.

Trustworthy Health and Wellness, David Kotz, Institute for Security,
Technology, and Society, Dartmouth College.  This talk addressed the
issues of authentication, privacy, trustworthy control, and
accountability in a mobile-rich and cloud-rich environment.  These
issues are critical in the healthcare domain, but the solutions are
applicable to other domains.

Patient Safety Challenges for Medical Device Innovation, Julian
Goldman, Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School.
This talk addressed the problem of when a medical-device-related
adverse event occurs, it is often difficult or impossible to identify
the root cause of the failure.  A Patient-Controlled Analgesia system
was used as a case study.

Track 3: Intervention, Control and Prosthetics

This track focused on robotic and networked medical solutions,
preventing attacks and outbreaks through constant monitoring, as well
as new, advanced prosthetics.  It featured two plenary talks.

Moving Beyond Current Approaches to a Broader View of Epilepsy
Monitoring, Steven Schater, Center for Integration of Medicine & 
Innovative Technology.  This talk focused on in-home monitoring
with video-EEG; and needs unmet by current approaches and emerging
technologies to surpass them.

Implantable Networks of Wireless Nanoelectronic Devices, Pedro
Irazoqui, Center for Implantable Devices, Purdue University.  This
talk focused on physically distributed networks of nanoscale wireless
sensors for  glaucoma IOP monitoring, seizure detection, prosthetic arm
control), and heart failure warning.  Such systems require a network of
implantable wireless devices, CMOS compatible nano-biosensors,
packaging, and energy harvesting.

Last Modified: 06/16/2017
Modified by: Scott A Smolka
